description: Adobe InDesign Creative Cloud is used for laying out printed materials such as brochures, ads, business cards or newsletters. Elements that are created in Illustrator and Photoshop are combined to create blocks of texts, photos or other artwork and put together in InDesign to create single or multi-page layouts. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
name: InDesign CC
subtitle: Desktop Publishing Application

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss what a viewer needs to know when getting started inside of Adobe InDesign. They talk about launching InDesign, opening existing document and creating new documents. They examine the some of the tools that will be used in later episodes.
episodes.title: Getting Started
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.081 --> 00:00:10.081
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.798 --> 00:00:14.597
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.597 --> 00:00:18.942
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and in today's
episode we're continuing through our

4
00:00:18.942 --> 00:00:21.684
series in
the Adobe Creative Cloud Suite 2015.

5
00:00:21.684 --> 00:00:24.440
More specifically we're
focusing on InDesign.

6
00:00:24.440 --> 00:00:26.630
Joining me in the studios
today is Erica Gamet.

7
00:00:26.630 --> 00:00:27.560
Erica, how you doing?

8
00:00:27.560 --> 00:00:28.208
>> I'm doing pretty good, Wes.

9
00:00:28.208 --> 00:00:29.235
Thanks.
>> Hey, very good.

10
00:00:29.235 --> 00:00:31.039
So what are we gonna be
diving into first today?

11
00:00:31.039 --> 00:00:33.520
>> Today,
we're gonna start at the very beginning.

12
00:00:33.520 --> 00:00:36.210
We're going to start
where you would start.

13
00:00:36.210 --> 00:00:38.830
When you first sit down
to work in InDesign

14
00:00:38.830 --> 00:00:41.810
with a black screen staring
you back in the face.

15
00:00:41.810 --> 00:00:42.870
So we're gonna start there.

16
00:00:42.870 --> 00:00:44.750
I'm gonna go ahead, and jump in, and

17
00:00:44.750 --> 00:00:48.150
show you a couple of different
ways to get into InDesign.

18
00:00:48.150 --> 00:00:51.220
The first one is that you would
launch the application, however,

19
00:00:51.220 --> 00:00:52.680
you launch applications.

20
00:00:52.680 --> 00:00:55.040
That could be down on your dock so

21
00:00:55.040 --> 00:00:56.620
it might be sitting on your
dock if you have a Mac.

22
00:00:56.620 --> 00:01:00.710
If you're on a PC you might
have it in your Start menu.

23
00:01:00.710 --> 00:01:03.580
And however, you would launch it we
can just click on it and launch it.

24
00:01:03.580 --> 00:01:05.370
I already had it running so
it's pretty quick,

25
00:01:05.370 --> 00:01:09.220
otherwise you get the start up screen
which may or may not take awhile.

26
00:01:09.220 --> 00:01:12.950
Sometimes the first time you launch it,
don't be afraid, it might take awhile.

27
00:01:12.950 --> 00:01:15.220
Also when you do an update,
it tends to take longer.

28
00:01:15.220 --> 00:01:17.240
That freaks people out sometimes.

29
00:01:17.240 --> 00:01:19.080
Just keep calm, it's all right.

30
00:01:19.080 --> 00:01:20.027
I'm gonna actually hide that.

31
00:01:20.027 --> 00:01:25.228
I'm gonna use a command that I use on the
Mac which is Cmd+H, a Ctrl+H on the PC.

32
00:01:25.228 --> 00:01:27.603
And I just wanna show you
this before we get in to it,

33
00:01:27.603 --> 00:01:31.141
that when I'm hitting my modifier keys,
down at the bottom I have the little

34
00:01:31.141 --> 00:01:33.657
symbols that show me what
modifier key I'm hitting.

35
00:01:33.657 --> 00:01:36.946
So you're gonna see that throughout
every episode that I work on, so

36
00:01:36.946 --> 00:01:38.886
just you can see what it is I'm hitting.

37
00:01:38.886 --> 00:01:41.960
Now I'm hitting the Cmd key or
the swirly propeller key or

38
00:01:41.960 --> 00:01:45.174
wherever we wanna call it
sometimes known as the Apple key.

39
00:01:45.174 --> 00:01:50.504
And I'm in the Apple of course, and on
the PC that's going to be the Ctrl key so

40
00:01:50.504 --> 00:01:55.096
if you see this symbol that's Cmd or
Ctrl, you'll here me say both

41
00:01:55.096 --> 00:01:59.880
commands what I speak about what key
I'm hitting so I say Cmd or Ctrl.

42
00:01:59.880 --> 00:02:01.420
Mac vs PC second.

43
00:02:01.420 --> 00:02:02.760
The other one is option.

44
00:02:02.760 --> 00:02:04.780
That's what that little crazy icon means.

45
00:02:04.780 --> 00:02:05.450
That's option.

46
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:11.280
And I have a control key on the Mac
that is right click on a PC,

47
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:14.030
or if you have a multi
button mouse on a Mac also.

48
00:02:14.030 --> 00:02:17.300
And again, I will say right-click or
Ctrl+click.

49
00:02:17.300 --> 00:02:19.140
And that is what the Shift key looks like.

50
00:02:19.140 --> 00:02:20.936
So you see these little symbols up here?

51
00:02:20.936 --> 00:02:23.660
It's only going to be when I'm doing
something with a modifier key,

52
00:02:23.660 --> 00:02:25.210
so don't be nervous with that.

53
00:02:25.210 --> 00:02:28.300
So I'm gonna do Cmd or
Ctrl+H to hide that cuz I wanna

54
00:02:28.300 --> 00:02:30.630
show you a couple different
ways to get in there as well.

55
00:02:30.630 --> 00:02:35.450
The other thing that we can do is we can
launch from an actual InDesign document.

56
00:02:35.450 --> 00:02:37.610
So I'm gonna open up a file here.

57
00:02:37.610 --> 00:02:38.795
I've just got some blank layouts.

58
00:02:38.795 --> 00:02:41.690
We're gonna talk about the different
layouts in just a minute.

59
00:02:41.690 --> 00:02:46.172
And I just want to zoom in a little and
show you what the icon looks like.

60
00:02:46.172 --> 00:02:50.280
So in depending on your version and
we are talking about CC 2015 but

61
00:02:50.280 --> 00:02:53.200
you might be on an older version and
most of what I cover,

62
00:02:53.200 --> 00:02:58.010
will actually apply to older versions,
probably going back as far as CS6 so,

63
00:02:58.010 --> 00:03:01.990
don't be worried if you are not
on the newest newest version.

64
00:03:01.990 --> 00:03:05.660
And I will try to point out if
that's a brand new feature as well.

65
00:03:05.660 --> 00:03:09.920
Sometimes trying to remember which version
of 2015 that new feature came out in

66
00:03:09.920 --> 00:03:14.220
is tricky, because with the Cloud
the updates are coming a lot faster.

67
00:03:14.220 --> 00:03:16.040
When they get a new feature
they just throw it in.

68
00:03:16.040 --> 00:03:20.900
For instance, just recently there was one,
and it just made a few minor tweaks, so

69
00:03:20.900 --> 00:03:23.570
yours might like look again slightly
different if you haven't done

70
00:03:23.570 --> 00:03:24.750
the latest update.

71
00:03:24.750 --> 00:03:30.390
But going back to the file,
the file here, the file format is .indd.

72
00:03:30.390 --> 00:03:31.558
That's the file extension.

73
00:03:31.558 --> 00:03:35.880
That's an InDesign document, and
as we go throughout the different episodes

74
00:03:35.880 --> 00:03:40.520
in the course we're going to actually, see
that there are some other extensions and

75
00:03:40.520 --> 00:03:44.460
I'll point those out as we go along,
but indd means an InDesign

76
00:03:44.460 --> 00:03:48.370
document it's something that we've
layed out in InDesign ready to go.

77
00:03:48.370 --> 00:03:51.280
So one of the things that we can
do is also just double-click,

78
00:03:51.280 --> 00:03:54.290
I'm one of those obviously and
it brings up an existing file.

79
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:57.920
I'm gonna close that,
Cmd or Ctrl+W to do that.

80
00:03:57.920 --> 00:04:01.130
Or we can always go to the File menu and
choose Close.

81
00:04:01.130 --> 00:04:03.650
All right, so
I'm gonna hide out of that as well.

82
00:04:05.050 --> 00:04:08.750
And the other thing we can do is we can
switch if you have a switcher on a Mac.

83
00:04:08.750 --> 00:04:13.010
We can just do the Cmd+Tab to
switch between open applications.

84
00:04:13.010 --> 00:04:14.200
So I'm gonna do that.

85
00:04:14.200 --> 00:04:16.660
And this is sort of how I start.

86
00:04:16.660 --> 00:04:18.550
I tend to launch the program and

87
00:04:18.550 --> 00:04:22.710
then I create a new document if I
don't have one already existing.

88
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:26.580
So to create a new document
we have to really think about

89
00:04:26.580 --> 00:04:30.902
where this document is headed,
not just let's just dive right in.

90
00:04:30.902 --> 00:04:33.240
Even though I said we're gonna
just dive right in which we are.

91
00:04:33.240 --> 00:04:36.420
But we're gonna dive in, we're gonna
think about this ahead of time.

92
00:04:36.420 --> 00:04:40.162
What is happening to
this file down the road.

93
00:04:40.162 --> 00:04:43.730
So at something I can't stress enough,
we don't live in a vacuum.

94
00:04:43.730 --> 00:04:47.310
Even if it's just me doing all
the production, I'm gonna start here and

95
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:50.980
I'm gonna make a printed version and
I'm gonna do a digital version.

96
00:04:50.980 --> 00:04:55.150
But I still need to know what
happens to that down the road.

97
00:04:55.150 --> 00:04:56.840
And as we go through the episodes,

98
00:04:56.840 --> 00:04:59.990
we will see all the considerations
that we need to make.

99
00:04:59.990 --> 00:05:03.070
So right now,
this might not make much sense to you.

100
00:05:03.070 --> 00:05:04.650
I'm telling you to think ahead.

101
00:05:04.650 --> 00:05:09.420
But maybe this is all very new to you,
and you're not even sure what is ahead.

102
00:05:09.420 --> 00:05:12.450
So we will learn that as we go through.

103
00:05:12.450 --> 00:05:14.747
So we're going to start
with a new document.

104
00:05:14.747 --> 00:05:19.111
And I'll discuss the considerations we
need to make but don't stress out too

105
00:05:19.111 --> 00:05:23.610
much if you don't understand that it will
all become clear but I want you to think

106
00:05:23.610 --> 00:05:27.390
about what the information is that
we're putting in each of this.

107
00:05:27.390 --> 00:05:31.740
So if you think I don't understand what
she meant by is a digital or print.

108
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:34.870
That's something you can notate
to yourself, I need to look at,

109
00:05:34.870 --> 00:05:36.590
am I doing this print or digital?

110
00:05:37.640 --> 00:05:40.710
So I'm gonna open up the new
document dialog box.

111
00:05:40.710 --> 00:05:44.180
So I can do Cmd or Ctrl+N to do that.

112
00:05:44.180 --> 00:05:47.930
Or, I'm gonna cancel out of that
just I can show you the menu option,

113
00:05:47.930 --> 00:05:51.880
File > New and then we scroll
over here to the new document.

114
00:05:51.880 --> 00:05:55.390
And you can see I've got the little
keyboard shortcut for me right here and

115
00:05:55.390 --> 00:05:57.510
depending if you're on the PC it
will look a little different but

116
00:05:57.510 --> 00:05:59.942
you'll see your shortcut indicated for
you.

117
00:05:59.942 --> 00:06:03.176
We're gonna talk about shortcuts
in an upcoming episode as well.

118
00:06:03.176 --> 00:06:07.357
So now we're gonna use the one
that's there, new document, and

119
00:06:07.357 --> 00:06:08.980
I can turn on Preview.

120
00:06:08.980 --> 00:06:10.590
I don't remember what
version this came in.

121
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:12.898
Somewhere in the cloud, probably 2014.

122
00:06:12.898 --> 00:06:16.400
Where I can actually see the page,
before we used to have to enter it.

123
00:06:16.400 --> 00:06:18.550
So you might not have that Preview button.

124
00:06:18.550 --> 00:06:22.460
And you enter the information and
hit OK and it's not what you look like.

125
00:06:22.460 --> 00:06:26.280
So they added this Preview button which
is great which means I can watch things

126
00:06:26.280 --> 00:06:28.990
being formed as I make changes to them.

127
00:06:28.990 --> 00:06:30.930
I can see that that is not what I want.

128
00:06:30.930 --> 00:06:34.020
I can also see that at the top
here it says Document Preset,

129
00:06:34.020 --> 00:06:35.802
it is something called postcards.

130
00:06:35.802 --> 00:06:40.335
Well, that's not what I want we're gonna
start with just a letter size page and

131
00:06:40.335 --> 00:06:44.208
we're going to work with single pages for
quite a while.

132
00:06:44.208 --> 00:06:46.940
We're not gonna get into it until we
learn a few more of the basics and

133
00:06:46.940 --> 00:06:49.180
start building on it,
then we can start adding pages.

134
00:06:49.180 --> 00:06:52.250
But for now we're gonna work for
the single page, letter size.

135
00:06:52.250 --> 00:06:56.460
It's a US letter so if you're not in the
US, of course, just adjust it accordingly.

136
00:06:56.460 --> 00:06:59.920
I am gonna work in inches as well so
adjust that accordingly.

137
00:06:59.920 --> 00:07:04.850
I'm gonna show you how to change that in
just a minute as well because InDesign

138
00:07:04.850 --> 00:07:09.560
does not ship with inches as
its default measurement, nor

139
00:07:09.560 --> 00:07:11.340
does it ship with anything metric.

140
00:07:11.340 --> 00:07:13.910
It ships with printing terms,
picas and points.

141
00:07:15.210 --> 00:07:17.210
So let's start putting in our information.

142
00:07:17.210 --> 00:07:19.440
So we see that
the Document Preset is postcards.

143
00:07:19.440 --> 00:07:23.060
It will probably show default
the first time you open that,

144
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:24.510
which is actually a letter.

145
00:07:24.510 --> 00:07:26.290
But we're not gonna worry
about that to start with,

146
00:07:26.290 --> 00:07:29.500
because what we're going to
do is we're going to enter in

147
00:07:29.500 --> 00:07:34.242
all the information in this dialog box,
and then we're gonna save that preset.

148
00:07:34.242 --> 00:07:36.630
We're gonna tell it what
that preset is called so

149
00:07:36.630 --> 00:07:39.260
we don't have to enter
all this stuff again.

150
00:07:39.260 --> 00:07:40.632
That's what we're trying to do.

151
00:07:40.632 --> 00:07:44.675
You're gonna see that I'm really about
automation and not doing the same thing

152
00:07:44.675 --> 00:07:47.568
over and over again, not just so
that I get done sooner but

153
00:07:47.568 --> 00:07:51.150
because I know it will be consistent
if I set this up ahead of time.

154
00:07:51.150 --> 00:07:54.000
So always be thinking am I
going to use this again?

155
00:07:54.000 --> 00:07:57.097
Maybe I need to name it in such
a way that I can find it again.

156
00:07:57.097 --> 00:07:59.448
So let's start first here with Intent.

157
00:07:59.448 --> 00:08:03.293
So it's going to ask you what are you
doing with this file, this goes back to,

158
00:08:03.293 --> 00:08:04.962
what are we doing with this file?

159
00:08:04.962 --> 00:08:07.092
And InDesign right there in your face and
it says,

160
00:08:07.092 --> 00:08:08.900
what are you doing with this file?

161
00:08:08.900 --> 00:08:10.201
So you have a couple different options.

162
00:08:10.201 --> 00:08:13.020
You have Print, Web, and Mobile.

163
00:08:13.020 --> 00:08:17.760
Now, Web and Mobile, there's some overlap
to that but Print, I'm gonna start with.

164
00:08:17.760 --> 00:08:20.466
And for me,
if I know that it's going to print and

165
00:08:20.466 --> 00:08:22.522
it's going to some digital format.

166
00:08:22.522 --> 00:08:25.551
Whether it's something I'm
setting up say for a web page or

167
00:08:25.551 --> 00:08:28.774
a web layout, which I generally
don't do a lot of in InDesign.

168
00:08:28.774 --> 00:08:31.350
But sometimes I might do a layout and
I know I'm going to send it.

169
00:08:31.350 --> 00:08:35.770
It's maybe just going to be a background,
and I didn't do it say, in Photoshop.

170
00:08:35.770 --> 00:08:37.293
I use InDesign a lot for things,

171
00:08:37.293 --> 00:08:41.426
because there's a lot of crossover between
Illustrator and Photoshop and InDesign.

172
00:08:41.426 --> 00:08:44.398
I even find that for
me InDesign makes more sense.

173
00:08:44.398 --> 00:08:47.490
I can always save it in a format
later that I would send to Photoshop.

174
00:08:47.490 --> 00:08:53.340
So I might say, I need a background for
a web page and I would set it up web.

175
00:08:53.340 --> 00:08:55.390
But let's say,
I'm going to go to print first, and

176
00:08:55.390 --> 00:08:57.980
we're gonna print
a version of this document.

177
00:08:57.980 --> 00:09:00.859
Let's just say, we're gonna work with
a one page ad, something very simple.

178
00:09:00.859 --> 00:09:04.255
And we're gonna print it, but
we're also going to make a PDF of it,

179
00:09:04.255 --> 00:09:05.710
which is digital.

180
00:09:05.710 --> 00:09:07.670
So Web or Mobile?

181
00:09:07.670 --> 00:09:10.030
So again, is it Web or is it Mobile?

182
00:09:10.030 --> 00:09:11.972
Well it's a PDFm, it's digital.

183
00:09:11.972 --> 00:09:13.160
Digital isn't an option.

184
00:09:13.160 --> 00:09:16.890
So we're gonna look at that,
but Print is more restrictive.

185
00:09:16.890 --> 00:09:21.294
So when we start looking at things
like resolution and colors, there's

186
00:09:21.294 --> 00:09:26.058
a more narrow space because when we go
to Print, we're actually putting ink or

187
00:09:26.058 --> 00:09:29.185
toner on paper or
other things that we can print on.

188
00:09:29.185 --> 00:09:32.310
But we're kinda working on
this more restrictive space so

189
00:09:32.310 --> 00:09:35.700
if we're going to print on something else,
start with Print.

190
00:09:35.700 --> 00:09:38.420
It's a little more narrow,
we can always work out from there.

191
00:09:38.420 --> 00:09:39.600
We start with the web,

192
00:09:39.600 --> 00:09:42.910
it assumes that it's already kind of
this loosey-goosey kind of thing.

193
00:09:42.910 --> 00:09:48.770
And then when we wanna go to print, it
says you can't, you set it up too broad.

194
00:09:48.770 --> 00:09:50.440
So hopefully that makes sense.

195
00:09:50.440 --> 00:09:51.696
So I'm gonna choose print to start with.

196
00:09:51.696 --> 00:09:56.240
And when I do that,
my page sizes down here are print related.

197
00:09:56.240 --> 00:09:58.670
So the ones at the top
are ones that I've added,

198
00:09:58.670 --> 00:10:00.790
because we can add custom
ones along the way.

199
00:10:00.790 --> 00:10:03.040
But the ones you'll probably
see are Letter, Legal, Tabloid,

200
00:10:03.040 --> 00:10:06.510
Letter half, which is eight and a half
by five and a half, and a legal half.

201
00:10:06.510 --> 00:10:08.378
We've got some European sizes as well.

202
00:10:08.378 --> 00:10:10.699
And a couple of really useless
ones down here at the bottom.

203
00:10:10.699 --> 00:10:12.070
I never use these, compact disc.

204
00:10:12.070 --> 00:10:16.085
That's basically the size of
the insert that goes in a compact disc.

205
00:10:16.085 --> 00:10:17.178
What's a compact disc?

206
00:10:17.178 --> 00:10:18.581
Nobody uses those anymore.

207
00:10:18.581 --> 00:10:20.927
So I don't even use those at all.

208
00:10:20.927 --> 00:10:23.844
I'm gonna start with letter,
pretty basic, as I said.

209
00:10:23.844 --> 00:10:27.030
And I'm going to tell how many pages.

210
00:10:27.030 --> 00:10:29.730
I generally start with 1 page, unless for

211
00:10:29.730 --> 00:10:32.655
a fact you're doing
a 12 page doc document.

212
00:10:32.655 --> 00:10:35.305
Maybe they so,
we need a 12 page newsletter.

213
00:10:35.305 --> 00:10:36.595
I tend not to put that in there,

214
00:10:36.595 --> 00:10:40.585
I just leave it at 1 because you can
add pages super easy on the fly.

215
00:10:40.585 --> 00:10:42.785
Unless you absolutely know how many pages.

216
00:10:42.785 --> 00:10:45.760
Start page,
I'm gonna leave that as page number 1.

217
00:10:45.760 --> 00:10:48.816
When we get into a later episode,
we'll talk about sections and numbers and

218
00:10:48.816 --> 00:10:50.020
we can change all that again.

219
00:10:50.020 --> 00:10:52.069
We don't need to worry about that.

220
00:10:52.069 --> 00:10:54.270
Over here is Facing Pages.

221

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate the Adobe Workspace. They examine panels including topics like application frames, the control panel, panel menus, customizing keyboard shortcuts and saving your documents versus a template.
episodes.title: The Adobe Workspace

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate working with design elements and guides. They look at text frames and placeholders. They explain how to use graphics frames, unassigned frames and modifying polygons. They also explore placing, moving and deleting guides. They dive into smart guides including smart spacing, smart cursors and smart dimensions.
episodes.title: Elements and Guides

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explore frames and paths within InDesign. They explain selecting, moving, copying, duplicating and resizing frames. They look at path concepts like points, segments, control handles and corner points. They demonstrate how to close a path, modifying paths through the Convert Direction Tool as well as moving and modifying points.
episodes.title: Frames and Paths

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss placing assets within InDesign. They look at the import options, replace options and proportional frames. They talk about placing graphics in frames, native .psd and .ai files as well as placing multiple files.
episodes.title: Placing Assets

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate how to manipulate images and frames within InDesign. They explain working with layers and the options associated with layers. They explore frame fitting, the options and frame auto-fitting. They talk about working with high-quality images and the considerations when using them.
episodes.title: Manipulating Images and Frames

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate ways to manage assets within Adobe InDesign. They discuss concepts such as gridify, the gap tool, various options inside of the link panel as well as inline and anchored objects.
episodes.title: Managing Assets

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss the various options when using effects to modify images within Adobe InDesign. They explain the effects panel, clipping paths, transparencies, blending modes, drop shadows, bevels, glows and feathers.
episodes.title: Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explain colors and swatches within Adobe InDesign. They explain some concepts on color like CMYK, RGB, styling, strokes and fills. They explore swatches including adding colors from the palette, defining and deleting unused colors. They also take a look at swatch libraries, gradient swatches, color stops, color ramps, linear vs. radial and applying color.
episodes.title: Color and Swatches

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate working with text within Adobe InDesign. They explain how to type, select, move and delete text inside a frame. They look at other concepts like dynamic spelling, spell check, auto correct, alignments, indents, as well as the character and paragraph panels.
episodes.title: Working with Text

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica talk about special characters and text effects. They explain attributes of special characters such as hidden characters, glyphs and white spaces. They look at text effects like wrapping, text on a path, changing case, the tabs panel, repeating values and paragraph rules.
episodes.title: Special Characters and Text Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explore text layouts within InDesign. They discuss OpenType, fractions, kerning pairs, and ligatures. They talk about importing text into InDesign such as import options, flowing, linking text, overset text, threads and smart text reflow.
episodes.title: Text Layout

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate working with tables within Adobe InDesign. They discuss importing tables from external applications like Microsoft Excel and Microsoft Word as well as creating new table from the table menu inside of InDesign. They look at the some table basics like the type tool, rows, columns, cells, colors, cell options , headers and embedding images.
episodes.title: Working with Tables

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss using layers within Adobe InDesign. They talk about concepts like creating and deleting layers as well as the various options that are available with layers. They explain moving objects, the visibility, locking and re-arranging layers.
episodes.title: Working with Layers

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss using pages and master pages inside of Adobe InDesign. They explain various options with using pages such as customization, adding pages, deleting pages, navigating pages, re-arranging pages and page labels. They also explore using master pages like creation, applying master pages to documents, primary text frames and smart text flow.
episodes.title: Pages and Master Pages

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica discuss InDesign libraries and Adobe Creative Cloud Libraries. They explain creating and opening libraries as well as adding items, adding groups of items and using items within an InDesign libraries.
episodes.title: Libraries

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica talk about working with styles within Adobe InDesign. They explain paragraph styles including creating a style from scratch or an existing type. They also look at character styles, nested styles and object styles.
episodes.title: Styles

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica demonstrate prepping the output of a project within Adobe InDesign. They explain transparencies and using native files from Illustrator, Photoshop, Acrobat and PDFs. They will also discuss non-transparencies, flatteners and separations.
episodes.title: Prepping the Output

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica talk about getting a project ready to print within Adobe InDesign. They explain the print window, common areas as well as saving,loading, and archiving styles. They explore the panel list and the various options such as general, setup, marks, bleeds, output, color management and more.
episodes.title: Printing

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explore Live Preflight and packaging within Adobe InDesign. They explain various digital output considerations, the Live Preflight, basic preflight summary and creating a package folder.
episodes.title: Preflight and Packaging

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Erica explain the last step on a project called exporting within Adobe InDesign. They discuss exporting to PDF and JPEG, as well as compression topics such as bicubic downsampling, automatic exporting and compression of text and line art.
episodes.title: Exporting
